results.title: The Battle of San Pietro
results.creator_credit: United States. Army Pictorial Service and John Huston
results.brief_description: Presents modern warfare from the soldier’s point of view. Stresses the number of men killed in taking one military objective. Shows how in the Allies Italian campaign, the people of San Pietro were too stunned to realise they had been liberated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: United States. Army Pictorial Service and John Huston

results.title: The Battle of Russia
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Frank Capra and United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Why we fight”.
This epic film unfolds the great history of Russia, and the defeat of Hitler’s Nazi armies. The depiction of the mightiest battle in war history, with a human life toll of 20 million Russians and 10 million Germans, becomes more than a first hand record of war; it is also an ode to a people’s courage and self sacrifice, and the end of Hitler’s “Mein Kampf”. Historic film sequences of “The Seige of Leningrad” features the miracle of a “frozen lake” which becomes a rescue highway for a city surrounded and doomed, an event which turned the tide of World War II.

results.title: The Battle of Britain
results.creator_credit: Frank Capra, Anthony Veiller and United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Why we fight”.
Illustrates the German air attack on Britain, particularly London, by the use of film shot during World War II. The role of civilians in the Battle of Britain is highlighted. Concentrates on the Blitz in London and Coventry after Dunkirk, combining actuality footage with many extracts from fiction films. This film is credited with reducing anti-British sentiment among American forces.

results.title: Bassoon and contrabassoon
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Music Techniques”.
One of a series of films designed to assist the musician and the music lover. In this film professional musicians show how the bassoon and contrabassoon are made, and played, demonstrate their range and tone, and show how to care for them.

results.title: Water management
results.creator_credit: Peter Dimond, South Australian Film Corporation and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description: Comic dramatisation is used to stress the importance of water conservation. Studies Adelaide’s water supply system to explain how and why water should be conserved. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Let there be light
results.creator_credit: Department of Defense and John Huston
results.brief_description: Produced by the American Department of Defence and banned for 35 years, this documentary deals with the treatment of soldiers suffering from war-induced psychotic and psychosomatic disorders. The camera records a wide range of emotional disabilities among the returning World War II veterans at Mason General Hospital at Long Island. Looks at the various methods of treatment which include hypnosis and truth-inducing drugs. The original purpose of the film was to convince the public, employers in particular, that soldiers suffering from neuro-psychiatric damage could be rehabilitated and resume civilian life. After seeing the finished product, the War Department withdrew the film for various reasons among them the invasion of the patients’ privacy and the fear that it would scare off potential recruit. Narrated by Walter Huston. Cinematography by Stanley Cortez.

results.title: The Rats of Tobruk
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel Productions and Charles Chauvel
results.brief_description: Grant Taylor, Peter Finch and Chips Rafferty are cast as three bold Australians in the war-time-morale-boosting feature, recreating war-torn Tobruk in a field near Camden, NSW. Although ostensibly a tribute to the Australian fighting spirits, “The Rats of Tobruk” is dominated less by rhetorical patriotism that by a sense of tragedy and heartbreak of war. George Wallace and Joe Valli appear frequently throughout the film to improvise some comic relief but the mood remains set by the three heroes as they soberly face their responsibilities in the war.

results.title: Heritage
results.creator_credit: Australian Expeditionary Films and Charles Chauvel
results.brief_description: Chauvel’s second sound feature was ambitious in scope spanning many decades in Australian history. The films traces the life and loves of James Morrison in colonial times and his descendant Frank Morrison in the 1930s struggling to survive on an outback station with the same determination as his ancestor. Cast, Franklyn Bennett, Norman French, Frank Harvey, Mary Maguire, Harold Meade, Margot Rhys, Joe Valli and Ann Wynn.
